including running 80 on ec2 windows and some other things all right so first why
do we care about Active Directory in the cloud well from our on premise experience we know that Active Directory
provides some great benefits for end-users they can sign on using you know passwords or certificates in have a
single sign-on experience for their desktops to gain access to corporate applications and the corporate
applications have the ability to utilize the Kerberos ticket that was issued to
the client and they can then verify who the user is they can identify what
groups that the user belongs to and provide access control that the applications using a group oriented
structure for access control which makes it pretty convenient for administration in addition to that we also have the
ability to join computers into the domain into the Active Directory domain
and apply group policy and group policy allows you to establish scripts that run
at various times I could log in or log off you can control security policies on
the machine you know there's a number of different things you can accomplish and you can do that in a hierarchical
structure where you can establish group policy for the site or you can go into
the domain or you can go down into an organizational unit and those policies
can be applied in a inheritance pattern down through the directory and that gives us a lot of convenience for
managing a large number of machines now well we believe that over time our
customers will be moving pretty much everything to the cloud we are also today and have always been very
committed to helping you find ways to easily make AWS an
extension of your on-premises environment that's something we call a hybrid cloud configuration and the
Active Directory being in the cloud is a key component of making that easy to do because you need to be able to bridge
where all your users are that are existing in your existing on-prem and and have those users have access to
applications and services that are running in the cloud and you want to deliver them these same exact benefits
in addition to that as you start moving workloads into the cloud you may be in a
situation where you're you know spinning up hundreds or maybe even thousands of instances of Windows up in the cloud and
you want a way of managing the group policy on those machines in the same way you might want to do that on Prem so
there's definitely a clear need for having Active Directory in the cloud so let's start talking a little bit about
what your options are one of the first options the option that
was originally pretty mature only option was having your Active Directory on-premises having a network connection
to the cloud and join all your ec2 instances that were in the cloud to your on-premise Active Directory so that was
one option the second option was that you could run Active Directory on an ec2
Windows instance in the cloud and move applications up into the cloud using
that directory and then a third option that we released about just a little
verbose December of 2015 was the Microsoft ad product which allows you to
have a you know real Active Directory that's running in the cloud but as a
managed service where AWS manages the service and so we're going to take a look at these three different options
that you have available to you and we're going to contrast you know what what the trade-offs are between these so that you
can you know pick which the right approaches for you so the first option
that we talked that I mentioned was running a Active Directory environment
in your on-premises network and joining the ec2 instances to your on-premises Network in this situation you have
domain controllers that are sitting in your corporate network here and the far left side and your workstations and
computers that are in your environment are domain join to that they're doing authentication authorization other LDAP
kind of queries to those domain controllers in that yellow dotted line on the left now in this situation what
you do is you create a VPN connection or a Direct Connect connection to a V PC in
the cloud and then you can stand up things like iis server sequel server or
dotnet applications that you have that need Active Directory access and those machines you you know from a best
practices standpoint it's good to have redundancy there in different availability zones so that you've got
some reliability and those machines are domain joined to the domain controllers
on your on-premises network which is the yellow lines with the arrows going back into your on-prem network now as you
have users that are in your on-prem network that need access to the applications that are running in the cloud the blue line is where those
application queries are going and they're hitting those applications in the cloud the applications are able to
get the Kerberos ticket from the client they're able to use the the fact that their domain join to verify the user and
identify which groups they're part of and apply the access control policies to
run those applications so that's that's a model that's been out there any of you using this model today
not too many couple just a few and there's a good reason for that you know
I talked to I've actually talked to a couple of customers today and what I was told is that they see about a six minute

from a networking standpoint if you're using an on-premise active directory use

to the directory contained within your VPC so all your ec2 instances are talking to an ad and the cloud they're

you start out with setting up a ec2 instance that's domain join to your on-prem and then you promote that up and

the cloud and all your domain joint it can happen in the cloud and all that gets replicated all the way through if
you're doing a trust model then you have fewer ports to open than you do if you
have a replication model because there's less less things that go on on a trust and so you can do a trust model if you
wanted to and in the case of Microsoft ad the only model that we support there
is a trust model which is the least exposed in terms that you're exposing your on-prem network the least in terms

and I'm going to go into those constraints and a little bit about what types of applications are appropriate

your costs this is a really affordable solution it's about half the price of
standing up your own ec2 instances and weed management so that can be a pretty cost effective also if you want to use
an RDS sequel server and have a managed sequel server in the cloud then you'll
need to have Microsoft ad if you want to have that work with on-prem users in the
same way that we had to adapt the deployment of Active Directory so that

your workloads there but they can't join that to your on-premises network because
then it breaks their ability to manage manage it as a service so in this case you would use RDS sequel server with

connect that together also if you're using other AWS enterprise applications
